details.title: An O(k/sup 2//spl middot/log(n)) algorithm for computing the reliability of consecutive-k-out-of-n: F systems
details.standardTitle: An O(k/sup 2//spl middot/log(n)) algorithm for computing the reliability of consecutive-k-out-of-n: F systems

p: Min-Sheng Lin received his M.S. in 1991 and Ph.D. in 1994 in Computer Science & Information Engineering from National Chiao Tung University (HsinChu, Taiwan). He is currently an Associate Professor at National Taipei University of Technology (Taipei, Taiwan). His research interests include the analysis of network reliability and performance evaluation of distributed computing systems.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Electr. Eng., Nat. Taipei Univ. of Technol., Taiwan
authors.name: Min-Sheng Lin

details.abstract: This study presents an O(k/sup 2//spl middot/log(n)) algorithm for computing the reliability of a linear as well as a circular consecutive-k-out-of-n: F system. The proposed algorithm is more efficient and much simpler than the O(k/sup 3//spl middot/log(n/k)) algorithm of Hwang & Wright.

citations.title: An O(k/sup 2//spl middot/log(n)) algorithm for computing the reliability of consecutive-k-out-of-n: F systems

links.abstract: A computer program is described for obtaining the reliability of a system composed of a number of interconnected sub-systems. The interconnections are such that at least r successive interconnected subsystems must fail in order for the system to fail. The approach treats the system as a dynamic redundant system and is implemented in a digital computer program. The program listing and examples are given in a Supplement.

context.text: Such systems were introduced by Kontoleon [1], and extensively studied in [2]–[11].

references.title: Reliability determination of a r-successive-out-of-n:F system
references.text: J. M. Kontoleon, "Reliability determination of a r-successive-out-of-n:F system", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. R-29, pp. 437, Dec. 1980.

links.abstract: The previous literature on consecutive-k-out-of-n: F systems gives recursive equations for the system reliability only for the special case when all component reliabilities are equal. This paper gives recursive equations for the more general case when the component reliabilities can be different from each other. Furthermore, reliabilities can be computed more quickly from these recursive equations than those previously given.

context.text: Such systems were introduced by Kontoleon [1], and extensively studied in [2]–[11].

references.title: Fast solutions for consecutive-k-out-of- n: F system
references.text: F. K. Hwang, "Fast solutions for consecutive-k-out-of- n: F system", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. R-31, pp. 447-448, Dec. 1982.

links.abstract: The linear (circular) k-of-n:F system has n linearly (circularly) ordered components. Each component either functions or fails. The system fails i.f.f.k consecutive components fail. This paper provides, in the i.i.d. case, recursive formulas and bounds for computing system reliability. It considers properties of system life distributions and, in the non i.i.d. case, questions of optimal system design.

context.text: Such systems were introduced by Kontoleon [1], and extensively studied in [2]–[3][11].

links.abstract: A simple, easily programmed algorithm is given for calculating a table of the coefficients for the failure probability polynomials associated with a consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system with i.i.d. components.

context.text: Such systems were introduced by Kontoleon [1], and extensively studied in [2]–[4][11].

links.abstract: A recursive algorithm obtains the reliability of a circular consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system. This algorithm works faster than those previously published.

context.text: Such systems were introduced by Kontoleon [1], and extensively studied in [2]–[6][11].

references.text: I. Antonopoulou, S. Papastavridis, "Fast recursive algorithm to evaluate the reliability of a circular consecutive-k-out-of-n: F system", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. R-36, pp. 83-84, Apr. 1987.

links.abstract: A consecutive-k cycle is a circular system such that the system fails if and only if any i consecutive components all fail. Reliabilities for consecutive-k cycles are usually computed by recursive equations. However, most recursive equations proposed so far for the cycle involve reliabilities for consecutive-k lines, requiring two passes where the first pass computes only the line reliabilities. A recursive equation involving cycles only is proposed that is simpler in form but much harder to und...

context.text: Such systems were introduced by Kontoleon [1], and extensively studied in [2]–[7][11].

Du & Hwang [7], and Zuo [9] derived a recurrence equation to compute the reliability of a linear system in \${\rm O}(k \cdot n)\$ time: with boundary condition \$R_{L} (n) = 1\$ for \$0 \leq n \leq k - 1\$.
The theorem proposed by Du & Hwang [7] is similar to (5), but it does not hold for the case of \$k+ 1\leq n< 2k\$.

references.title: A direct algorithm for computing reliability of a consecutive-k-cycle
references.text: D. Z. Du, F. K. Hwang, "A direct algorithm for computing reliability of a consecutive-k-cycle", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. R-37, pp. 70-72, Jan. 1988.

links.abstract: A consecutive-k-out-of-n:F (consecutive-k-out-of-n:G) system consists of an ordered sequence of n components such that the system is failed (good) if and only if at least k consecutive components in the system are failed (good). In the present work, the relationship between the consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system and the consecutive-k-out-of-n:G system is studied, theorems for such systems are developed, and available results for one type of system are applied to the other. The topics include system...

links.abstract: J.G. Shanthikumar (IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol.R-36, p.546-50, Dec. 1987) proposed a new system structure called the consecutively connected system, which is a generalization of the well-studied consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system. An O(n/sup 2/) algorithm was developed for its reliability evaluation. This work studies the structure of the consecutively connected system and provides more efficient algorithms for its reliability evaluation. The complexities of the algorithms are of order O(kn) for l...

context.text: Such systems were introduced by Kontoleon [1], and extensively studied in [2]–[9][11].

Du & Hwang [7], and Zuo [9] derived a recurrence equation to compute the reliability of a linear system in \${\rm O}(k \cdot n)\$ time: with boundary condition \$R_{L} (n) = 1\$ for \$0 \leq n \leq k - 1\$.

references.title: IEEE Trans. Rel.
references.text: M. J. Zuo, IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. R-42, pp. 484-487, Sept. 1993.

links.abstract: The consecutive-k-out-of-n:F and related systems have caught the attention of many researchers since the early 1980s. The studies of these systems lead to better understanding of the reliability of general series systems, In computation and structure. This paper is mainly a chronological survey of computing the reliability of these systems.

references.title: IEEE Trans. Rel.
references.text: M. T. Chao, J. C. Fu, M. V. Koutrces, IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. R-44, pp. 120-127, Jan. 1995.

links.abstract: The fastest generally-recognized algorithms for computing the reliability of consecutive-k-out-of-n:F systems require O(n) time, for both the linear and circular systems. The authors' new algorithm requires O(k/sup 3/spl middot/log(n/k)) time. The algorithm can be extended to yield an O(n/spl middot/max{k/sup 3/spl middot/log(n/k), log(n))} total time procedure for solving the combinatorial problem of counting the number of working states, with w working and n-w failed components, w=1,2,...,n.

context.text: Such systems were introduced by Kontoleon [1], and extensively studied in [2]–[11].
Hwang & Wright [11] derived an \${\rm O}(k^{3} \log(n/k))\$ time algorithm for computing the reliability of a Con/k/n:F system with i.i.d. components.
The proposed algorithm requires \${\rm O}(k^{2}\cdot\log(n))\$ time, and is therefore more efficient & much simpler than that of Hwang & Wright [11].
H&W: algorithm of Hwang & Wright [11] LIN: algorithm proposed in this paper.
H&W: algorithm of Hwang & Wright [11] UN: algorithm proposed in this paper.
Tables I and II compare the running time (in seconds) between the algorithm of Hwang & Wright [11], and that proposed in this paper.
The proposed algorithm clearly outperforms that of Hwang & Wright [11].

references.title: An
references.text: F. K. Hwang, P. E. Wright, " An \${rm O}({rm k}^{3}log({rm n}/{rm k}))\$ algorithm for the consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system ", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. R-44, pp. 128-131, Mar. 1995.

context.text: The approach of Gries & Levin [12] can be used to accelerate the computation of (1), which yields an efficient algorithm, based on a matrix representation, to compute the order-\$k\$ Fibonacci numbers using the recurrence equation, \$F_{n } = F_{n - 1 } + F_{n - 2 } +\cdots + F_{n - k}\$.

In fact, according to Gries & Levin [12], rather than computing \$k^{2}\$ elements in the product matrix of two \$k\times k\$ matrices, only \$k\$ independent elements need to be appropriately computed, so that the other elements in the resulting product matrix can be derived from these \$k\$ independent elements.
Theorem 1 [12] states that the independent elements of \$M^{r}\$ are the elements in its last row, \$m_{k,1}^{r}, m_{k,2}^{r},\ldots, m_{k, k}^{r}\$ for any \$r \geq 1\$.
Theorem 1 [12]: For \$i=k -1, k - 2, \ldots,1,\$ .

references.title: Computing fibonacci numbers (and similarly defined functions) in log time
references.text: D. Gries, G. Levin, "Computing fibonacci numbers (and similarly defined functions) in log time", Information Processing Lett., vol. 11, no. 2, pp. 68-69, 1980.
